summary: Worst place I've ever worked, TOXIC!
pros: The benefits are good. Some of the people that I worked with were pretty decent they followed the mission well. I believe they have good intentions at OSF.
cons: Management is terrible. If someone doesn't like you they are able to bully you and there are no repercussions. I have never worked in a department that was so awful and toxic in ALL of my life. I would never recommend, to a friend, a position in Sterile Processing Department!

summary: Resources & staffing good, culture was terrible
pros:
Alaris pumps & epic for charting is a preference of mine, �short staffing� was the charge nurse having a team which is better than most places
- free college while employed
cons:
Without being raised as a new graduate at this facility the staff nurses treat newcomers like they don�t know anything. There is a rigid adherence to how the nursing body has always done things as opposed to best practice or the companies own current policies. Leadership prefers testaments of long running staff members to discern their best moves. Human Resources for employee relations is not an asset, they strongly side with leadership and are generally unreachable. This network leads to cliques running the unit, as they can report and expect responses to planned cohesive statements whether their singling out of a staff member is warranted, truthful, or not.
- very low hourly pay for the state

summary: They got too big and don't listen anymore
pros: Mostly great coworkers. Most people truly want to do the best they can and feel they have a calling to serve. The mission is talked about often. They have some really great managers, that work hard for their employees and others who are about climbing the ladder.
cons: They have gotten too big and have lost sight of their employees. They no longer listen to the true issues. ALL decisions have to go through corporate in Peoria, which means nothing gets done. There is no direct contact with employees anymore. HR is non existent unless you mess up. You never see them and have to go to them. How do you do that when you are overloaded with patients? It used to be a great place to work, but now it's only about $, and if you aren't a nurse or a doctor you don't matter.
